Description: A common inflammatory skin condition affecting hair follicles and oil glands, characterized by pimples, blackheads, whiteheads, and sometimes cysts or nodules. It most frequently occurs during puberty but can affect people of all ages. Acne typically appears on the face, forehead, chest, upper back, and shoulders. The condition can range from mild to severe and may cause scarring and emotional distress. Effective treatments are available, but it often requires a combination approach and persistence.

Description: A pre-cancerous skin condition characterized by rough, scaly patches or lesions on sun-exposed areas, most commonly appearing on the face, lips, ears, forearms, scalp, neck, and back of hands. These lesions develop from years of sun exposure and are considered the earliest stage in the development of skin cancer. They range in color from skin-toned to reddish-brown and feel rough or sandpaper-like to the touch. Untreated actinic keratosis has a small but significant risk of progressing to squamous cell carcinoma.

Description: A group of blistering skin disorders characterized by large, fluid-filled blisters (bullae) that appear on the skin and mucous membranes. These conditions can be serious, sometimes life-threatening, and require prompt medical attention. Bullous diseases include pemphigus vulgaris, bullous pemphigoid, and dermatitis herpetiformis. The blisters can rupture easily, leaving painful erosions that are prone to infection. These conditions often have autoimmune origins where the body attacks its own skin proteins.

Description: A fungal infection caused by overgrowth of Candida species, particularly Candida albicans. It can affect various parts of the body including skin, mouth, throat, genitals, and nails. On skin, it typically appears as red, moist patches with satellite pustules or papules at the edges, most commonly occurring in skin folds (armpits, groin, under breasts). The condition thrives in warm, moist environments and can cause intense itching and discomfort. While usually not serious, it can be persistent and recurrent in some individuals.

Precautions: Keep skin clean and dry, especially in folds; Use antifungal powders in moist areas; Wear loose, breathable cotton clothing; Control blood sugar levels if diabetic; Take probiotics when on antibiotics; Apply antifungal creams (clotrimazole, miconazole) as directed; Change out of wet clothing promptly; Maintain healthy weight to reduce skin folds; Avoid sharing personal items like towels; Consult doctor if infection recurs frequently

Description: Also known as drug rash or drug hypersensitivity reaction, this condition refers to various skin reactions caused by medications. Reactions range from mild rashes to severe, life-threatening conditions like Stevens-Johnson syndrome or toxic epidermal necrolysis. The timing varies from immediately after taking a drug to weeks later. Common presentations include hives, morbilliform rashes (measles-like), fixed drug eruptions, and photosensitivity reactions. Diagnosis requires careful medical history and sometimes skin testing.

Description: Various skin conditions caused by parasitic insects or arthropods, including insect bites, stings, and infestations. Common examples include mosquito bites, bed bug bites, scabies, lice, flea bites, and tick bites. These typically cause itchy, red bumps or welts on the skin, sometimes with a central punctum. Some infestations like scabies cause burrows under the skin, while others like lice cause visible insects or eggs (nits). Some bites can transmit serious diseases like Lyme disease or West Nile virus.

Description: A chronic inflammatory skin condition characterized by small, shiny, flat-topped papules that are typically purple in color and extremely itchy. Lichen planus can affect skin, mucous membranes (mouth, genitals), hair, and nails. The exact cause is unknown but it's thought to be autoimmune. The condition often follows a relapsing-remitting course and can last from months to years. Wickham's striae (fine white lines) are a characteristic feature visible on the surface of lesions.

Description: Specifically cutaneous lupus erythematosus, this autoimmune disease causes various skin manifestations including the characteristic butterfly rash across cheeks and nose. There are three main types: acute cutaneous lupus (malar rash), subacute cutaneous lupus (annular or psoriasiform lesions), and chronic cutaneous lupus (discoid lupus causing scarring). Skin involvement can occur with or without systemic lupus. Lesions are often photosensitive and may cause permanent scarring and pigment changes.

Description: Commonly known as nevi, moles are clusters of pigmented cells (melanocytes) that appear as small, dark brown spots on the skin. Most people have between 10-40 moles that typically develop in childhood and adolescence. While most moles are benign, they can sometimes develop into melanoma, a dangerous form of skin cancer. Moles vary in color, shape, and size. The ABCDE rule helps identify suspicious moles: Asymmetry, Border irregularity, Color variation, Diameter >6mm, Evolution (changing).

Description: A chronic, non-contagious autoimmune disease that accelerates the life cycle of skin cells, causing them to build up rapidly on the surface. This results in thick, silvery scales and dry, red patches that are sometimes painful or itchy. Common types include plaque psoriasis (most common), guttate, inverse, pustular, and erythrodermic psoriasis. About 30% of people with psoriasis develop psoriatic arthritis, which causes joint pain and stiffness. The condition typically follows cycles of flares and remissions.

Description: A chronic inflammatory skin condition primarily affecting the face, characterized by persistent redness, visible blood vessels, and sometimes small, red, pus-filled bumps. It typically begins with facial flushing that progresses to persistent redness. There are four subtypes: erythematotelangiectatic (redness and visible vessels), papulopustular (acne-like breakouts), phymatous (skin thickening), and ocular (eye involvement). Description: Common, benign skin growths that appear as waxy, raised, brown, black, or tan lesions with a 'stuck-on' appearance. They typically develop in middle age or later and increase in number with aging. These growths are not cancerous and don't become cancerous, but they can be confused with skin cancer. They vary in size from tiny to over an inch and can appear anywhere except palms, soles, and mucous membranes. Sometimes they become irritated or inflamed from friction.

Description: The abnormal growth of skin cells most often caused by UV radiation exposure. Skin cancer can appear as new growths, sores that don't heal, changing moles, or scaly patches. Early detection is crucial for successful treatment, especially for melanoma.

Description: Cumulative skin damage from repeated UV exposure over years, leading to photoaging and various skin changes. Includes wrinkles, fine lines, leathery texture, age spots (liver spots), freckles, telangiectasias (broken blood vessels), and actinic keratosis. Unlike acute sunburn, this damage builds up gradually and may not become apparent until years later. It's the primary cause of premature skin aging and significantly increases skin cancer risk.

Description: Common fungal infections caused by dermatophytes that feed on keratin in skin, hair, and nails. Different types include: tinea corporis (ringworm on body), tinea cruris (jock itch), tinea pedis (athlete's foot), tinea capitis (scalp ringworm), and tinea unguium (nail fungus). Lesions typically appear as red, scaly, circular patches with raised edges, often itchy. Despite the name 'ringworm,' no actual worm is involved. These infections are contagious through direct contact or contaminated surfaces.

Description: Benign or malignant growths arising from blood vessels, including hemangiomas, vascular malformations, angiosarcomas, and Kaposi's sarcoma. Description: Inflammation of blood vessels leading to reduced blood flow, tissue damage, and various skin manifestations. Cutaneous vasculitis appears as palpable purpura (raised purple spots), ulcers, nodules, or livedo reticularis (net-like pattern). It can be primary (limited to skin) or secondary to systemic disease. Some forms are mild and self-limited, while others can affect internal organs and be life-threatening. Description: An autoimmune condition characterized by loss of skin pigment (melanin), resulting in smooth, white patches on the skin. It occurs when melanocytes (pigment-producing cells) are destroyed. The extent and rate of pigment loss are unpredictable. Vitiligo can affect any part of the body, including hair and inside of mouth. It's often associated with other autoimmune disorders like thyroid disease, alopecia areata, and pernicious anemia. Different types include common warts (hands), plantar warts (feet), flat warts (face, legs), filiform warts (face, neck), and genital warts. Warts are contagious through direct contact or contaminated surfaces. They can be stubborn to treat and often recur. Most warts are harmless but can be painful, especially plantar warts. Some HPV strains are associated with cancer (especially genital warts).
